primary_topic: GenUI architecture fundamentals and three-tier component system
design_patterns: three-tier architecture (primitives/patterns/configs)
config-driven UI (JSON descriptors instead of TSX)
universal renderer (single engine for app + AI output)
tool-based streaming (AI SDK pattern)
component registry pattern
schemas_or_types: ComponentEntry interface (component, schema, category)
ComponentDescriptor (type, props, children, when, unless, bind, repeat, on)
RenderContext (state, actions, theme, locale)
streaming_patterns: AI SDK tool-based streaming (7 tools replace 20 custom events)
tool state machine (input-streaming → input-available → output-available)
streaming tool inputs (partial tool inputs rendered as they arrive)
gml_tags_referenced: Not GML-specific; discusses replacing GML with universal renderer
reusable_code: Complete conceptual framework for moving from bespoke React components to config-driven rendering. 27 primitives + 1 renderer + JSON configs = entire app UI.
key_signals: Superagent has TWO rendering systems (React + GML); GenUI unifies into ONE
Bundle size reduction from 2.08MB to ~60KB (1.83MB app + 177KB GML → 30KB primitives + 5KB renderer + 15KB configs)
Enables AI to generate not just content but UI structure (Level 3 generativity)
Config-driven approach enables white-labeling, theming, AI-generated interfaces
Tool-based streaming eliminates custom 20-event protocol complexity
Universal renderer supports all UI (app chrome, reports, websites, dashboards)
Time to MVP: ~1 week for 1 engineer (27 primitives + renderer + 5 page configs)

primary_topic: Implementation of 27 atomic UI primitives with Zod schemas
design_patterns: component registry pattern (flat map of ComponentEntry)
Zod schema validation (every component has schema)
Tailwind CSS utility classes
props-as-JSON pattern (components accept flat props objects)
category-based organization (primitive/container/data/media/form/feedback)
schemas_or_types: ComponentEntry { component, schema, category }
TextSchema (content, variant, weight, color, truncate, maxLines)
ButtonSchema (label, variant, size, icon, disabled, fullWidth, action)
CardSchema (padding, border, shadow, rounded, background, children)
RowSchema (gap, align, justify, wrap, children)
GridSchema (cols, gap, children)
TableSchema (columns, rows, compact)
ChartSchema (traces, layout, height)
FormSchema examples (TextInput, Switch with name/checked/label)
streaming_patterns: No streaming in registry itself; primitives are rendering targets for streamed descriptors
reusable_code: Complete, production-ready primitive component library. 27 components with Zod schemas can be copied directly into implementation. All use Tailwind CSS with no external dependencies beyond React + Zod.
key_signals: 27 primitives organized into 6 categories (10 primitive, 8 container, 4 data, 2 media, 2 form, 3 feedback)
Each component takes flat props object (no nested structure)
Schema validation advisory (renders anyway if invalid in dev mode)
No inter-primitive imports (composition via children prop)
Icons, skeletons, spinners have size presets (xs/sm/md/lg)
Forms support multiline TextInput with autoexpanding
Data components (Metric, Table, Chart, Timeline) support streaming-friendly props
Card/Row/Column are flex-based layout primitives, Grid uses CSS Grid

primary_topic: Universal renderer engine that converts JSON descriptors to React components
design_patterns: recursive descriptor rendering (tree traversal)
conditional rendering (when/unless)
data binding ($-prefixed state paths)
event binding (on handlers mapped to actions)
repeat/loop support (array iteration with 'as' variable)
state path resolution (dot notation: 'chat.messages.0.content')
pattern registry expansion (resolve type → look up pattern → expand)
schemas_or_types: ComponentDescriptor { type, props, children, key, when, unless, bind, repeat, on }
PatternRegistry { [name]: (props: any) => ComponentDescriptor }
RenderContext { state, actions, theme, locale }
PageConfig { id, title, layout, initialState, actions }
streaming_patterns: Renderer is stateless (context changes trigger re-renders)
Streaming updates state → re-render with new context
Conditional sections (when/unless) hide/show based on state changes
reusable_code: Core renderDescriptor function is production-ready. Handles all rendering logic: type resolution, prop validation, state binding, event binding, conditionals, loops. Can be copied and extended with custom pattern registry.
key_signals: Single renderDescriptor function handles app + AI output rendering
State path resolver supports nested object/array access (e.g., 'messages.0.content')
String interpolation ($var notation) for dynamic prop values
Repeat loops with context augmentation per item
Event handlers map to action function names (onClickHandler called with onClick event)
Patterns expand recursively (nested pattern resolution)
Prop validation via Zod but renders anyway in production
Key prop for React list rendering (descriptor.key or index fallback)
RenderContext includes theme and locale for internationalization

primary_topic: Tier 2 composed patterns built from primitive descriptors
design_patterns: pattern factory pattern (props → descriptor tree)
composition via children arrays
conditional children (spread operator with ternary)
loop composition (map over props array)
data binding within patterns ($ string interpolation)
schemas_or_types: ChatMessage pattern props { role, content, attachments[], badges[], timestamp }
ChatInput pattern props { placeholder, isStreaming }
PlanProgress pattern props { phases[], isStreaming }
ReportHeader pattern props { title, generatedDate, tocItems[] }
SourceCard pattern props { index, title, description, favicon, sourceType, siteName }
NavSidebar pattern props { logo, items[], sections[], user, collapsed }
SettingsCard pattern props { title, children[] }
WebsitePreview pattern props { title, src, actions[] }
streaming_patterns: PlanProgress shows Spinner vs StatusDot based on isStreaming flag
ChatInput button changes from 'send' to 'stop' when isStreaming
BrowserAgentBanner emits pulse animation when agent is active
reusable_code: All 17 patterns are directly usable. Each pattern function returns a descriptor tree that can be expanded by renderer. Patterns demonstrate composition techniques: conditional children, loops, data binding within markup.
key_signals: 17 patterns composed from primitives eliminate ~60 bespoke React components
Patterns replace Superagent's hand-coded page components
Each pattern is a pure function (props in → descriptor out)
Patterns can nest (ChatList contains multiple ChatMessage patterns)
Conditional rendering via spread operator + ternary (clean composition)
Data binding within patterns ($msg.content, $user.name, etc.)
Streaming state drives button/indicator changes (isStreaming prop)
Two category patterns: chat/report (3 + 4), pipeline (2), app chrome (5), content (3)
NavSidebar supports collapsed state with icon-only layout

primary_topic: Complete page configurations for 6 pages (home, chat, account, tasks, modal, error)
design_patterns: page config as JSON (replaces TSX page components)
nested descriptor trees (Row → Column → Card → Text)
routing via route map (match path to config)
repeat binding to state arrays (repeat: { source, as })
conditional rendering (when: 'state.flag')
Tab components with activeTab binding
schemas_or_types: PageConfig { id, title, layout, initialState, actions }
Route map { [path]: PageConfig }
streaming_patterns: PlanProgress shown conditionally when 'stream.isActive'
BrowserAgentBanner shown when 'stream.browserAgentActive'
Website preview shown when 'chat.hasWebsite'
reusable_code: Complete 6-page app specification. Each page is a ~50-100 line JSON config. Chat page demonstrates complexity (nested Row/Column, repeat binding, conditional sections, tab switching). Can be used as template for other apps.
key_signals: 6 full pages specified as JSON (no TSX needed for pages)
Home page with suggestions grid and deliverable type cards
Chat page with split layout (sidebar, center messages, right preview)
Account settings page with 2-column grid + cards
Tasks page with tab switching
Modal page for chat info (sources/files/activity tabs)
Error page for 404 handling
Route map enables dynamic routing ({'/': homePage, '/chat/[chatId]': chatPage})
All state bindings use $ notation ($chat.title, $currentUser, $suggestions)
Tabs support badges (message counts)
Empty states shown conditionally (EmptyState when 'projects.isEmpty')

primary_topic: AI SDK tool definitions replacing Superagent's 20-event custom protocol with 7 standard tools
design_patterns: tool-based UI generation (AI calls tools, client renders based on tool parts)
discriminated unions (tool parts typed by tool name)
streaming tool inputs (partial inputs rendered as they arrive)
client-side tools (user confirmation, input gathering)
server-side tools (execution and side effects)
schemas_or_types: Tool schema from Vercel AI SDK (createTool with description + inputSchema)
updateResearchPlan input { phases[] with { title, status, tasks[] } }
streamReportSection input { sectionTitle, content, sectionIndex, isComplete }
reportSources input { sources[] with { title, url, description, sourceType, favicon }, totalCount }
askClarification input { message, options[] }
browserAgentAction input { action enum, url, description }
renderUI input { component descriptor { type, props, children } }
deployWebsite input { title, code (TSX source) }
streaming_patterns: Tool inputs stream in (input-streaming state)
Tool outputs appear when complete (output-available state)
Partial tool inputs skeletoned (Skeleton component shown during streaming)
Client-side tool rendering (askClarification waits for user response)
Server tools execute and return results
reusable_code: Complete tool definitions with Zod schemas. Server route handler and client renderer code both included. Can be adapted for any Vercel AI SDK implementation. RouteHandler shows POST /api/chat/message pattern with streamText, convertToModelMessages, and tool invocation.
key_signals: 7 tools replace 20 custom events (updateResearchPlan, streamReportSection, reportSources, askClarification, browserAgentAction, setChatTitle, renderUI, deployWebsite)
No custom streaming protocol; AI SDK handles state machine (input-streaming → input-available → output-available)
Each tool has inputSchema for validation and code generation
Client renderer maps tool parts to GenUI patterns (tool-updateResearchPlan → PlanProgress pattern)
Streaming content shown as Skeleton until complete
Clarification rendering waits for addToolOutput call (human-in-the-loop)
renderUI tool accepts ComponentDescriptor directly (universal UI rendering)
deployWebsite returns { title, url, status: 'live' }
Server route uses stopWhen: stepCountIs(20) for multi-step research
All tool inputs validated by Zod schemas

primary_topic: Detailed comparison of Superagent bespoke architecture vs GenUI config-driven approach
design_patterns: Two-system vs one-system (React + GML vs universal renderer)
Code vs data (TSX page files vs JSON configs)
Custom protocol vs standard tools (20 events vs AI SDK)
Custom state vs Zustand (Redux vs lightweight client state)
streaming_patterns: Custom streaming (20 event types) vs tool-based (7 tools + AI SDK state machine)
gml_tags_referenced: GML system (16 components: gml-row, gml-primarycolumn, gml-chart, gml-blockquote, etc.)
Comparison shows GenUI unifies GML + React into single 27-primitive system
reusable_code: Comparison table provides clear mapping from Superagent architecture to GenUI alternatives. Useful for refactoring decisions.
key_signals: Component reduction: 60 React files + 16 GML components → 27 primitives + 17 patterns
Page definition: TSX files → JSON configs
Report rendering: GML parser → universal renderer (same primitives as app)
Streaming: 20 custom events + custom Redux → 7 AI SDK tools + Zustand
Bundle size: 1.83MB app + 177KB GML + 22KB stream → ~60KB total
Adding widget: new React file + parser + Redux → add to registry (~20 lines)
Theming: modify CSS + potentially code → swap design tokens config (zero code)
White-labeling: fork entire app → new config set + token set
Three levels of generativity: content → structure → full interface
Time to implement: ~1 week MVP, ~2 weeks full parity

primary_topic: Complete reverse-engineered Superagent architecture from clean room browser analysis
components_defined: 16 GML components (gml-Row, gml-PrimaryColumn, gml-Chart, gml-Blockquote, gml-InfoBlockMetric, gml-InfoBlockEvent, gml-InlineCitation, gml-ViewReport, gml-ViewWebsite, etc.)
design_patterns: streaming via fetch() + ReadableStream + TextDecoder (not WebSocket/SSE)
NDJSON line-by-line parsing
plan decomposition (PlanSet → Plan → PlanTask linked lists)
parallel research agents (5-15 tasks per research phase)
multi-section report streaming
replay system (useReplayStream hook)
schemas_or_types: ChatMessage { id, creator_type, deliverable_type, entities[], hydrated_content, is_answer, needs_clarification_message }
PlanSet { chat_id, creator_user_id, plans[] }
Plan { id, status, title, plan_tasks[], used_sources[], previous_plan_id }
PlanTask { id, title, status, message, previous_task_id }
Entity { identifier, entity_type, content_artifact_id, stored_entity_id, mimetype, title, created_at }
GML component schemas (29 Zod schemas found)
streaming_patterns: 20 stream event types (stream_start, heartbeat, task_update, node_report_preview_start/delta/done, message_delta, references_found, browser_use_start/stop, clarification_needed, done, error)
has_async_entities_in_progress flag drives polling after stream ends
Browser agent with await_user_input for human-in-the-loop
gml_tags_referenced: 16 GML tags documented: gml-Row, gml-PrimaryColumn, gml-SidebarColumn, gml-HalfColumn, gml-Header, gml-Blockquote, gml-GradientInsightBox, gml-InfoBlockMetric, gml-InfoBlockEvent, gml-InfoBlockStockTicker, gml-InlineCitation, gml-ChartContainer, gml-ViewReport, gml-ViewGeneratedDocument, gml-ViewPresentation, gml-ViewWebsite, gml-DownloadFile
reusable_code: Complete API endpoint list (29+), stream event types (20), GML tag reference (16), Redux action catalog (28+), feature flags (16), page routes (16), state models. This is the source material for GenUI design.
key_signals: Next.js Pages Router + React 18 + Radix UI + Tailwind CSS stack
Redux custom implementation (not RTK) with request caching
Ory Kratos for auth (OIDC/Google OAuth)
Google Cloud Storage for artifacts (gs://credit-doc-analysis-artifacts-us-central-prod/)
Zod for validation (29 schemas in GML chunk)
NDJSON streaming proven at scale (20-30KB chunks)
70+ unique task node IDs observed (node_xyz_depth pattern)
248-680 entities per chat (81+ web pages, 157+ API data points)
GML streaming parse bug: incomplete JSON causes 80+ error spam per response
Plan execution: always search_agent → strategy → parallel research (5-15 tasks) → synthesis → generation
Browser agent can pause for user input (login, CAPTCHA, confirmation)
Website deployment to Vercel/Netlify with subdomain

primary_topic: Deep technical analysis of Superagent's streaming engine, data model, and API surface
design_patterns: NDJSON streaming protocol (proven in production)
Plan-driven execution (PlanSet → Plans → Tasks → Results)
Multi-model gateway pattern (router for different LLMs)
Feature flags for progressive rollout
Signed URLs for time-limited artifact access
schemas_or_types: Session object with AAL (Authenticator Assurance Level)
Workspace { billingStatus, hasHadTrialPeriod, id, planType, userId }
Chat flow: user message → POST /api/chat → { chat_id, chat_message_id } → open stream → events → polling for completion
Subscription { current_period_start/end_unix_timestamp, payment_method, promo_code_details, trial_end_unix_timestamp }
streaming_patterns: Lifecycle: POST /api/chat → stream_start → heartbeat → task_update → node_report_preview_* → message_delta → ai_message → message_is_answer → done
Visibility handling: chat_visibility_changed_while_streaming event
Polling fallback when streaming stalls (has_async_entities_in_progress flag)
gml_tags_referenced: 18 GML tags with complete schema validation
reusable_code: Complete streaming protocol specification, polling strategy, API endpoint catalog, Redux action patterns, feature flag structure. All validated in production at scale.
key_signals: Streaming tested with 55 script tags and 1.83MB _app chunk
Website status polled every 5s (GET /api/website/status with XHR)
Websocket state unused (pristine: true, connected: false) — proves HTTP/ReadableStream is the right choice
Download/upload progress tracked separately from requests cache
Normalized data cache for entity deduplication
16 feature flags enable progressive feature rollout
Multi-section report streaming enables progressive rendering (not waiting for full synthesis)
Retry flow: POST /api/chat/retry creates new PlanSet with 'Retry XYZ' title
User feedback tracking exists but implementation unclear
Task node IDs follow semantic naming (node_domain_descriptor_depth)
Chat visibility monitoring prevents state loss on tab switch
Replay system records initialStreamedMessage for re-watch capability

primary_topic: Architectural replication guide comparing Superagent, DocuIntelli, and NYQST platform design patterns
design_patterns: prompt-to-deliverable pipeline (decompose → dispatch → stream → synthesize → render)
12-agent parallel orchestration (CRE example with 12 research subagents)
linked-list ordering for plans/tasks (previous_plan_id, previous_task_id)
tool registry abstraction (9 tools in Superagent, extensible)
source pack governance (domain allowlists, reputation scores)
multi-deliverable type handling (report, website, slides, document, code)
policy profiles (FAST vs DEEP response modes)
universal primitives (same components for all UI)
schemas_or_types: ChatMessage { id, creator_type, deliverable_type, hydrated_content, is_answer, error_type, entities[], needs_clarification_message }
PlanSet { chat_id, workspace_id, plans[] }
Plan { id, title, status, previous_plan_id, used_sources[], plan_tasks[] }
PlanTask { id, title, status, message, previous_task_id }
Entity { entity_type, content_artifact_id, stored_entity_id, generation_status }
SourcePack { url, title, domain, search_query, relevance_score, reputation_score, retrieved_at }
Run { id, user_prompt, deliverable_type, response_mode, status, stream_id, created_at, completed_at }
streaming_patterns: NDJSON over HTTP ReadableStream (not SSE due to auth issues in DocuIntelli)
Plan creation event emitted first
Task progress events streamed throughout
Content deltas streamed (node_report_preview_delta or content.delta)
Run completion event marks final state
Error events for retry logic
gml_tags_referenced: GML discussion as predecessor; SML (Structured Markup Language) proposed as evolution
reusable_code: Complete build specification for NYQST SuperAgent including: database schema (41 tables), API specification, streaming protocol, orchestrator design, tool registry, LLM model strategy, frontend component architecture, 7-phase implementation plan. Production-grade specification ready for engineering.
key_signals: Superagent origin: 'credit-doc-analysis' by Preemo, evolved to general-purpose research platform
Captured user prompt: CRE metrics library generation (very complex, 12 parallel research subagents)
Decomposition quality: 12-agent orchestration with semantic task naming (node_cre_lifecycle_stages_research_1)
260+ sources cited in single report (46 extracted from cache)
Tech stack alignment: Next.js + React 18 + Tailwind → React 19 + Vite + Tailwind 4 (Superagent proven, newer tooling)
Auth choice: Ory Kratos (Superagent) → Supabase Auth (simpler, RLS proven)
Database: Unknown (Superagent) → PostgreSQL + pgvector (DocuIntelli pattern)
Streaming: NDJSON over ReadableStream (Superagent proven) vs SSE (DocuIntelli failed due to auth)
Tool registry: 9 sources in Superagent (Brave, Firecrawl, Polygon, Quartr, Kalshi, Crunchbase, FRED, QuiverQuant) → 8 tools + document processing
LLM strategy: Model tiering (Haiku for cheap, Opus for synthesis)
Risk mitigation: Superagent's 60-citation provenance system validates governance approach
MVP: 7-phase plan with gates at each phase (foundation → streaming → plans → synthesis → deliverables → documents → polish)
Architectural decisions table shows how Superagent evidence informs each choice
